original_sent: So that’s in the low 20s, and that’s post the May employment report.
text_output: NEUTRAL - The sentence does not provide any clear indication of a hawkish or dovish stance. It is simply stating a numerical value in relation to the May employment report.

original_sent: At the time of our FOMC meeting in January, prospects for continued economic growth remained favorable, and we judged that monetary policy was well positioned to support that outlook.
text_output:
NEUTRAL
The sentence does not indicate any bias towards tightening or easing of monetary policy. It simply states that the economic growth prospects were favorable and the current monetary policy was well positioned to support that outlook.

original_sent: There’s a lot more demand for risk sharing, for liquidity services, and so on.
text_output:
NEUTRAL

The sentence does not indicate a clear stance on monetary policy. It simply describes a trend in demand for certain financial services.

original_sent: By getting unemployment down, we hope to bring back to work some of the people who’ve been out of work as long as they have and, in that respect, try to avoid the longer-term consequences of people being out of work for months at a time.
text_output: DOVISH - The sentence suggests that the FOMC is focused on reducing unemployment and bringing back people who have been out of work for a long time. This indicates a willingness to support the economy and potentially ease monetary policy to achieve this goal.

original_sent: But also we want to see inflation move up back to our 2 percent objective over the medium term, and so seeing above-trend growth and continuing tightness—greater tightness in labor and product markets—I think that will help us achieve our objective as well with respect to inflation.
text_output:
HAWKISH
The speaker is advocating for above-trend growth and greater tightness in labor and product markets, which suggests a desire for a tighter monetary policy. Additionally, the speaker mentions wanting to see inflation move up to the 2 percent objective, which further supports a hawkish stance.

original_sent: That is a positive for growth.
text_output: NEUTRAL - The sentence does not provide any indication of whether the monetary policy should be tightened or eased. It simply states that the outcome is positive for growth, which could be interpreted as a neutral stance.

original_sent: We have a 2 percent symmetric inflation objective, and, for a number of years now, inflation has been running under 2 percent.
text_output: DOVISH - The sentence suggests that inflation has been running below the 2 percent target for a number of years, indicating that the current monetary policy may be too tight. Therefore, the statement is dovish as it suggests a potential easing of the monetary policy to achieve the inflation target.

original_sent: So the term “trend inflation”—usually there are a variety of statistical techniques that can be used to extract a trend from a series.
text_output:
NEUTRAL

The sentence does not express any clear stance on monetary policy. It is simply discussing statistical techniques for extracting a trend from a series.

original_sent: Inflation pressures remain muted, and indicators of longer-term inflation expectations are at the lower end of their historic ranges.
text_output: DOVISH - The sentence suggests that inflation pressures are low and inflation expectations are also low, indicating that there is no urgency to tighten monetary policy. This stance is dovish as it suggests a willingness to maintain or even ease the current monetary policy.

original_sent: During this time of reopening, we are likely to see some upward pressure on prices, and I’ll discuss why.
text_output: DOVISH - The sentence suggests that there may be upward pressure on prices during the reopening period, which could be interpreted as a reason to ease monetary policy to support economic growth.

original_sent: And, and those are—that’s again—that goes to keeping this episode as short as it can be and avoiding unnecessary business bankruptcies, unnecessary household bankruptcies, and unnecessary long-term stays of unemployment or supporting people through them so that they can maintain their financial footing and their lives and be able to go back to work in a productive way.
text_output:
DOVISH

The sentence suggests a focus on avoiding negative economic outcomes such as business and household bankruptcies and long-term unemployment. The emphasis on supporting people to maintain their financial footing and return to work in a productive way indicates a desire to ease the monetary policy.

original_sent: So you have seen a shift this time in most participants’ assessments of the appropriate path for policy, and, as I tried to indicate, I think that largely reflects a somewhat slower projected path for global growth—for growth in the global economy outside the United States—and for some tightening in credit conditions in the form of an increase in spreads.
text_output: DOVISH - The sentence suggests that there has been a shift in the participants' assessments towards a slower projected path for global growth and tightening in credit conditions. This indicates a need for easing of the monetary policy to support the economy.

original_sent: Inflation, in fact, is under control, and starting to come down.
text_output: DOVISH - The sentence suggests that inflation is currently under control and decreasing, which implies that there may not be a need for tightening monetary policy. This stance is more accommodative and therefore can be classified as dovish.

original_sent: It will include all data relevant to our dual mandate of stable prices and maximum employment.
text_output: NEUTRAL - The sentence simply states that the data included will be relevant to the dual mandate of stable prices and maximum employment, without indicating a preference for either hawkish or dovish policy.

original_sent: So in—in—in U-6, the U-6 level of unemployment has tripled from 7 percent to 21 percent.

original_sent: So, if we maintain a highly accommodative monetary policy for a very long time from here and the economy performs as we expect—namely, it’s strong and the risks that are out there don’t materialize—my concern will be that we will have much more tightening in labor markets than you see in these projections.
text_output:
HAWKISH
The sentence suggests that maintaining a highly accommodative monetary policy for a long time may lead to tightening in labor markets, which implies a concern for potential inflationary pressures. Therefore, the stance is hawkish.

original_sent: That should drive productivity.

NEUTRAL
The sentence does not provide any indication of whether the monetary policy should be tightened or eased, therefore it is considered neutral.

NEUTRAL
The sentence does not express a clear stance on monetary policy. It simply states a fact about inflation spreading across services.

original_sent: I would further say that I think it’s important to emphasize that we’re not going to mechanically take the interest rate projections that participants provide and just build policy off of that.
text_output: NEUTRAL - The sentence does not indicate any bias towards tightening or easing of monetary policy. It simply emphasizes that the interest rate projections provided by participants will not be the sole basis for policy decisions.

original_sent: But—so I would just say that our—that there are many things that go in, as you know, to, to setting asset prices.
text_output: NEUTRAL - The sentence does not express any clear stance on monetary policy. It simply acknowledges that there are many factors that influence asset prices.

original_sent: Last year, we had 1.9 percent productivity, which is much higher.

NEUTRAL

original_sent: And no, we’re not—we, we have not at all changed our view, and I haven’t changed my view that inflation running above 2 percent, moderately above 2 percent, is a desirable thing.
text_output: DOVISH - The speaker is indicating that they believe inflation running above 2 percent is desirable, which suggests a willingness to tolerate higher inflation levels. This stance is generally associated with a more accommodative monetary policy.

original_sent: I mean, it really depends on how long it takes for wages and, more than that, prices to come down for inflation to come down.
text_output: DOVISH - The sentence suggests that the speaker is more concerned about inflation coming down and is waiting for wages and prices to decrease. This implies a willingness to wait for the economy to improve before taking any action, which is a dovish stance.

original_sent: And then, what the statement emphasizes, and this is the same language we used in December and January, we used the language especially if inflation is running below our 2 percent objective.

original_sent: Long-term unemployment in the current economy is—is the worst—really the worst it’s been in the postwar period.

original_sent: If we—if we analyze inflation data and conclude that, clearly, transitory influences are holding down inflation, I do not want to say that we would respond to that.

original_sent: But many other commodity prices have fallen further, and the reason I would give for that is that the emerging markets—China, the rest of Asia, and some other parts of the world—plus Europe, of course, are softer, and so global commodity demand is weaker.

The sentence does not express a clear stance on monetary policy. It simply explains that financial conditions are taken into consideration when making decisions about monetary policy, but does not indicate whether the stance is hawkish or dovish.

NEUTRAL

original_sent: So it’s a serious economic problem for the United States, but it’s—it’s got underlying causes that are not related to monetary policy or to our response to the pandemic.

NEUTRAL

text_output: DOVISH - The sentence suggests that if the projected improvement in the baseline outlook is not seen, then the pace of interest rate increases would be more gradual. This implies a potential easing of the monetary policy.

original_sent: And if the stock theory of the portfolio is correct, which we believe it is, holding all of those securities off of the market and reinvesting and still keeping the, you know, rolling-over maturing securities, will still continue to put downward pressure on interest rates.
text_output: DOVISH: The sentence suggests that holding securities off the market and reinvesting them will continue to put downward pressure on interest rates. This implies an easing of monetary policy, as lower interest rates make borrowing cheaper and stimulate economic growth.

original_sent: We have continued to provide guidance, the same guidance that we have for some time, that says the Committee “anticipates that, even after employment and inflation are near mandate-consistent levels, economic conditions may, for some time, warrant keeping the target federal funds rate below levels the Committee views as normal in the longer run.” I know that’s a mouthful, but it says, in effect, that the Committee believes that the economic conditions that have made recovery difficult, we’re getting beyond them.
text_output: DOVISH - The sentence suggests that the Committee believes that the economic conditions are improving and recovery is becoming easier. NEUTRAL

original_sent: Admittedly, some of the wage increases is being eaten away by inflation.

text_output: DOVISH - The sentence suggests that the unemployment rate is higher than what is being reported, which implies that the economy may not be performing as well as expected. This could lead to a call for easing of monetary policy to stimulate economic growth.
